This isn’t my usual post, but something is seriously wrong with the job market.

I’ve been reconnecting with former colleagues across different industries, and nearly every conversation has led to the same realization—something is seriously wrong with the job market.

Talented, highly experienced professionals with 20+ years in their fields are being laid off at unprecedented rates. Corporate restructuring is leaving entire teams uncertain about their future. Meanwhile, official unemployment numbers don’t tell the full story—the reality of layoffs, automation, and disappearing job security is being overlooked.

The way AI is reshaping the workforce is only making this worse. Entry-level jobs—once the stepping stone for future leadership—are disappearing, and without them, we’re setting ourselves up for a massive leadership vacuum in the years ahead.

This is personal. These are real conversations with real people who have built careers, led teams, and driven industries forward—only to be replaced, outsourced, or deemed “too expensive.”

I took the time to deep dive into what’s actually happening beyond the headlines, and the picture is alarming.

We hear this constantly, and the employment implications feel scary.

But a groundbreaking 2025 study from the National Bureau of Economic Research reveals this is just one part of a 3-part story. The other parts paint a much more optimistic picture:
🤹 Workers naturally shift efforts to tasks AI can't do well
🚀 AI-adopting firms grow faster and hire more workers overall

Bottom line: Despite alarming headlines, the research shows that while AI substitutes for labor at the task level, the aggregate employment effects are surprisingly small because these three forces largely offset each other.

What does this mean for HR and business leaders?
📈 To achieve the growth effects documented in the paper - increased sales (9.5%), higher employment (6%), greater profits (8.5%), and improved productivity (7.6%) - you need a comprehensive workforce strategy that breaks down work into tasks, identifies AI opportunities, and shifts skill development accordingly.

For most of human history, people worked the land. Then came the Industrial Revolution, shifting workers to factories. In recent decades, industry declined, and the service sector exploded—today, 79% of jobs are in services.

But what happens when algorithms take over services?

Machines first replaced physical labor. Now, AI is automating cognitive tasks once thought uniquely human. Yet, while intelligence has advanced dramatically, consciousness has not—there’s been a decoupling of the two that we once assumed were inseparable.

Agriculture → Industry → Services → … what comes next?

The answer isn’t just about competing with AI—it’s about evolving with it. Throughout history, humans have adapted by redefining work, creativity, and purpose. And while AI may match or surpass human intelligence in many domains, consciousness—our ability to feel, reflect, and create meaning—remains uniquely ours.

Emotions, with all their complexity and messiness, aren’t a flaw of human nature—they’re what make us interesting, unpredictable, and deeply connected to one another. AI can analyze, predict, and optimize, but it doesn’t experience joy, curiosity, or compassion.

The next shift isn’t the end of human value—it’s the beginning of something new.

Lately, I keep asking myself: Why do so many companies think about AI in such an uninspired, boring and even harmful way? Instead of imagining new possibilities, some CEOs seem obsessed with one idea: "Can I just replace my team with AI?"

The National Eating Disorders Association (NEDA) thought they could. They replaced their human-staffed helpline with "Tessa," an AI chatbot. What happened? The bot started offering harmful advice – telling people with eating disorders to count calories and lose weight. The public outrage was massive. Rightfully so. NEDA had to take the chatbot down. But the real kicker? This decision came right after their human helpline staff voted to unionize.

I wonder: How did anyone think this was a good idea?

Because at the end of the day, those who use your services often don’t care whether you use AI or not. They care about feeling heard, respected, and understood.

My take on this is not that AI is not yet there, but that we should finally find the actual power and possibilities of AI in our real world. AI is so much more than just a cost-cutting tool, it enables things that were not possible before – decision-making backed up by massive amount of data, real-time use of data, automation of massive processes for single users, providing useable interfaces for non-experts onto complex knowledge or systems...

Okay, back to the original topic (layoffs because of AI takeover) and the here and now.

Better customer service and a $1.4 billion revenue boost.

Will AI Agents Reshape SaaS? A Look at the Buzz
SaaS—might face a shakeup from AI agents, according to a bold idea floating around tech circles lately.

The theory lays out a three-step shift, and it’s got IT pros talking.
-- First, hiring slows. Companies lean on AI to boost efficiency, trimming the need for human operators.
-- Next, AI agents plug straight into SaaS tools via APIs, skipping dashboards and human interfaces entirely.
--Finally, within 2-3 years, AI takes over, running tasks solo, leaving SaaS as a quaint relic. It’s a striking vision: humans clicking software could feel as outdated as saddling up a horse.

What’s Fueling the Hype
Some see this as the future taking shape.
Picture AI crafting tools on the fly—software that’s built, used, and discarded for each job, no static platforms required.

Others argue AI agents could become the primary users, shifting SaaS from serving people to feeding machine-driven workflows.

The appeal is clear: tailored solutions, faster outputs, less bloat.

The Pushback Holds Weight
Not so fast, say the skeptics—and they’ve got a point.

SaaS isn’t just interfaces; it’s robust infrastructure—think APIs and scalable systems. Companies like Shopify prove it, thriving with API-driven setups that AI could enhance, not erase.

Big players like Salesforce bank on enterprise loyalty and workflows tied to human oversight—tough to uproot in a couple years.

One view even pegs SaaS as the steady foundation AI builds on, not replaces.

The Middle Path: Winners and Losers
This isn’t a clean sweep either way.

API-first firms like Stripe could ride this wave smoothly, meshing with AI like clockwork.

But those UI-heavy tools—CRMs with more menus than a diner? They might struggle to keep up.

It’s like travel agents after online booking hit: some adapted, others faded. SaaS could follow suit, with lean players gaining ground.

What the Data Suggests
Reports from late 2024—like one from HFS Research—nod to AI pushing toward flexible, orchestrated systems, echoing Salesforce’s cloud rise in the 2000s.

TechCrunch countered later that year, pointing out SaaS subscriptions and upsells are too sticky to unravel fast.

Gartner’s $208 billion SaaS market estimate for 2024, up 18% annually, backs the staying power.
No hard numbers lock this down—it’s still a forecast, not a fact sheet.

Where This Lands
This debate pits bold predictions against practical realities—a tech classic.

The 2-3 year timeline sparks excitement among forward-thinkers picturing autonomous, API-fed workflows.

But momentum, human control, and SaaS’s proven scale suggest a slower shift—evolution, not extinction.

API champs will likely pull ahead, clunky platforms will scramble, and IT pros get a front-row seat to the action.

For now, it’s a solid bet SaaS adapts and thrives alongside AI, not under it.

Remember that there was a MASSIVE drop in employment in 2020 as companies furloughed then laid of millions of workers in the course of about four months, then just as rapid a need for rehiring as those same companies realized they needed to build out their remote workforce they'd just let go, pushing salaries sky high as a consequence. That peaked in late 2021 as it looked like we were coming out of the pandemic and companies were bulging at the seams with workers that were no longer required, so we went through a painful process of layoffs and ads dried up.

Significantly, the whole AI period shows barely a blip in comparison, which is truly odd given the hype surrounding it. Very few companies were actually hiring (something that I - and I suspect a lot of other people can attest to), which is exceptional when you realize that this was new technology that is/was supposed to transform the way that we did business. Indeed, the level of job postings is almost where it was at the bottom of the Trump recession and well below where it was before the pandemic.

Why? I honestly do not believe it really has all that much to do with genAI. Rather, I think we're seeing the effects of moving to everything to the cloud. The pandemic accelerated that process dramatically, in effect bringing demand forward by about a decade. However, what that has also done is create a trough in demand for IT services - people have what they need, and it's hard to argue with customers that they need yet another data service.

Investors set their expectectations based upon the returns from the pandemic, but that was also very anomalous. Personally, I think that GenAI is going to take a while to really mature, probably well into the 2030s, and more than likely IT is going to underperform the general market for the next few years or so.

There are two other factors. The first is that there was a practice among larger companies in particular during the pandemic of warehousing talent, in part to keep them out of competitors' hands when labour was tight. As the pandemic waned, many of them were let go, and companies went into a mode where they shifted away from having full time workers to hiring contractors and consultants. You're seeing a shift now in the kind of work being done, with shorter projects (the typical 18 month project is now doable in 3-4 months, as an example) and more extended periods between them. Some of this is AI, but more of it is simply that you're tying together services rather than having to build out complex components.

The second factor is that software is no longer a differentiator for most companies. AI Inside never really gained all that much traction; indeed, people have become bored (and turned off) by it as a marketing device, something that was inevitable.

Wait doesn’t that mean adoption should be faster because agentic AI can truly automate the operational part?

Theoretically yes. But AI is not adopted in a silo. It means onboarding a new platform, a new technology, training people on it, and so on. This is where HR teams are facing a huge crunch.

If it’s the former, then why isn’t OpenAI making those improvements available to all users? If it’s the latter, then companies aren’t paying for AI—they’re paying for hidden human labor.

Either way, OpenAI hasn’t explained why this product is worth the cost of a car every month—especially when companies can hire overseas workers for far less.

So what’s really going on?

It looks like AI agents aren’t replacing workers—they’re justifying mass layoffs.

In the U.S., large-scale layoffs require companies to notify the state under the WARN Act. But if a company claims, “We’re replacing 1,000 workers with 10 AI agents,” regulators are likely to accept that explanation without question. The catch? No one checks if the company fires those AI agents a month later.

This creates a legal loophole for downsizing—a convenient excuse to fire workers without scrutiny. And once the dust settles? Companies can quietly outsource those jobs overseas at a fraction of the cost.

The real question isn’t whether AI can replace workers—it’s whether AI is just being used as an excuse to fire them.

🌟 Why AI is Controversial: Exploring the Risks and Ethical Challenges in Its Integration 🌟

Artificial intelligence \(AI\) is rapidly integrating into various sectors worldwide, including healthcare, education, banking, and more, promising significant improvements in efficiency and innovation. However, the increasing prevalence of AI has sparked intense debate and controversy among experts and communities. This article explores the risks associated with AI and the ongoing discussions surrounding its use.

### \*\*Risks Involved in the Use of Artificial Intelligence\*\*

1. \*\*Loss of Jobs\*\*
AI is replacing human jobs on a massive scale, raising concerns about unemployment and economic shifts. Many professionals are worried as AI quickly takes over roles across industries, with a significant number of companies planning to reduce their workforce by adopting this technology.

2. \*\*Increases the Problem of Bias and Discrimination\*\*
AI systems, which rely on data for operations, often generate biased results. This is particularly evident in areas like facial recognition and hiring processes, where flawed data can lead to discriminatory decisions, impacting fairness and equity in various sectors.

3. \*\*Affects Privacy and Surveillance\*\*
The widespread use of AI has raised significant privacy concerns. AI technologies can collect vast amounts of data, leading to potential information leaks and misuse. Some countries also use AI for surveillance, threatening personal privacy and civil liberties.

4. \*\*Lack of Regulation\*\*
The regulation of AI varies widely across countries. While some nations implement strict laws, others lack any formal framework to govern AI use. This inconsistency raises the risk of AI being exploited for unethical purposes.

5. \*\*Use of AI in Warfare Techniques\*\*
AI is increasingly being utilized in military technology, including the development of autonomous weapons. This trend reduces human control in warfare, posing significant risks of dangerous consequences and ethical dilemmas.

### \*\*Conclusion\*\*
While AI offers immense potential, its risks cannot be overlooked. Experts emphasize the need for ethical solutions and responsible management of AI to mitigate these challenges. The future of AI depends on addressing these concerns and ensuring its benefits are realized without harm to humanity.

AI Can Tell If You’re About to Quit Your Job… 

Before You Even Know It! 🤯

Imagine updating your LinkedIn profile, adding a few new skills, and suddenly, BOOM! AI has you marked as a “high flight risk.” 🚀

Sounds like something out of a sci-fi movie, right? Well, it’s happening.

Companies are using predictive analytics + AI to spot job hoppers before they start hunting.

Here’s how it works:

🔍 AI Watches Your Moves

Every time you tweak your profile, endorse a mate, or start connecting with recruiters, AI takes notes.

It tracks:

✅ How often you update your profile
✅ How many new connections you’re making
✅ Whether you’re engaging with job posts
✅ Any sudden skill upgrades or endorsements

Basically, if you start acting like someone who’s looking for a new gig… AI knows.

📊 AI Scores Your “Likelihood to Leave”

Using machine learning, companies create a “job hopping score” based on past patterns.

If the AI thinks you’re about to jump ship, your boss might get a heads-up before you even make a decision.

🚀 Why Do Companies Care?

Losing employees is expensive, hiring, training, and replacing people costs a fortune.

So businesses use this tech to:

-> A Life Lost vs. A Robot Lost

Consider the engine and coupling staff in the. These workers perform dangerous tasks—manually coupling and decoupling train cars, often under extreme conditions. The number of accidental deaths and injuries in this sector is alarming. From 2010 to now, countless railway workers have lost their lives performing duties that could have been automated.

Now, think about this—if a robot were assigned to this task and it malfunctioned or got damaged, we could simply build another one. But when a human life is lost, the impact extends far beyond numbers. Families are shattered, communities suffer, and the loss ripples across generations.

So why are we investing AI talent into making robots that serve food, rather than robots that could save lives?

Title: Embracing AI: A Shift in the Job Landscape

As artificial intelligence (AI) continues to evolve and permeate various industries, the discourse around its impact on the job market intensifies. While some fear job displacement, others foresee a transformation in the nature of work. Whichever side of the debate one stands on, there’s no denying that AI is reshaping the employment landscape, compelling us to adapt and innovate.



Traditionally, automation has been synonymous with job loss. However, history has shown that technological advancements often lead to the creation of new roles and industries. The key lies in how individuals, organizations, and policymakers respond to these shifts. Instead of resisting change, we must embrace it, leveraging AI to enhance productivity, efficiency, and creativity.



AI excels at repetitive tasks, freeing up human capital to focus on higher-value activities that require emotional intelligence, critical thinking, and problem-solving skills. Consequently, jobs that demand human creativity, empathy, and adaptability are less susceptible to automation. Rather than viewing AI as a threat, we should view it as a tool to augment our capabilities and amplify our impact.



Moreover, AI is revolutionizing industries by enabling personalized experiences, predictive analytics, and data-driven decision-making. From healthcare to finance, retail to manufacturing, AI-driven insights are driving innovation and unlocking new opportunities. However, this transformation necessitates upskilling and reskilling the workforce to remain relevant in an AI-powered economy.



Furthermore, as AI takes on mundane tasks, it’s essential to prioritize the ethical and responsible development of AI systems. Ensuring transparency, fairness, and accountability in AI algorithms is paramount to mitigate biases and promote trust. Collaboration between technologists, policymakers, and ethicists is crucial to establish guidelines that uphold human values in the age of AI.



In conclusion, the rise of AI presents both challenges and opportunities for the workforce. While certain jobs may become obsolete, new avenues for employment and innovation will emerge. By embracing AI, upskilling our workforce, and fostering ethical AI practices, we can navigate the evolving job landscape with confidence and resilience.

As a ProcessAgilist, automating workflow using AI, I'm frequently confronted with the question: Doesn't automation lead to "job loss"? Isn't someone going be fired because of you? How can you live with yourself? Aren't we just automating jobs away?

That's a tough one, and I get it. If you've made your money a certain way for a while, disruptive technology... well... Disrupts!

Automation changes the way we work, no doubt about it. It often makes certain roles obsolete. History has repeatedly shown us that when a door closes, a window opens—often to a room with a much broader view. Remember the Pony Express? Revolutionary in its day, yet it couldn't outpace the advent of the telegraph. And look at us now, communicating across the globe in an instant on LinkedIn. Gone are the days of milling flour by hand, and your daily bread we're all so thankful for, is within easier reach for everyone due to automation.

My job isn't to replace people with machines; it's to find ways to let machines do the repetitive, boring, tedious stuff so that people can focus on what they're best at — solving real problems, being creative, creating genuine connections.

The way I see it, I help people transition from one opportunity to the next, upping their game in a world where change is the only constant.

Sure, it's challenging, but it's also exciting. We're not just workers; we're learners and innovators. And if history's shown us anything, it's that, as a species, we're pretty good at adapting.

If you're not part of the automation process, you will certainly be disrupted BY it. Learn the trade being created by the automation, rather than defending the trade supplanted by it. The microwave has saved countless hours of toil. Restaurants learned to harness the power of microwave technology to make better food faster, rather than trying to outlaw them. People won't be directly replaced by AI, but those who know how to use it will surely replace those who don't.

Let’s not fear automation. Let's use it as a tool to create a future where work is more about what we bring to the table as humans — creativity, empathy, innovation. AI is revolutionizing recruitment—from scanning resumes and shortlisting candidates to even conducting initial interviews. The promise? Faster, more efficient, and data-driven hiring decisions. But the big question remains: Can AI truly understand human potential?

Many organizations are adopting AI-powered recruitment tools to eliminate human bias, streamline processes, and improve candidate matching. However, critics argue that AI might be reinforcing biases instead of removing them. After all, an algorithm learns from past data, and if that data contains biased hiring patterns, the AI may unknowingly replicate them.
The Debate: Pros & Cons of AI in Hiring

✅ Why AI is a Game-Changer:
✔ Faster Hiring: AI screens thousands of resumes in seconds, reducing the workload for recruiters.
✔ Objective Decision-Making: AI-based systems focus on skills and qualifications, potentially reducing bias.
✔ Better Candidate Matching: AI can analyse vast amounts of data to find the best fit for a role.

⚠ Concerns About AI in Recruitment:
❌ Bias in Algorithms: AI learns from historical data, which may contain inherent biases, leading to unfair hiring decisions.
❌ Lack of Human Judgment: Can AI assess soft skills, emotional intelligence, and cultural fit as effectively as a human recruiter?
❌ Data Privacy Issues: AI relies on large datasets, raising concerns about data security and ethical hiring practices.
With technology rapidly evolving, we must ask ourselves: Is AI making hiring better or worse?

AI in Hiring: Is It Fair or Flawed? 🤖

AI is revolutionizing recruitment—from scanning resumes and shortlisting candidates to even conducting initial interviews. The promise? Faster, more efficient, and data-driven hiring decisions. But the big question remains: Can AI truly understand human potential?

Many organizations are adopting AI-powered recruitment tools to eliminate human bias, streamline processes, and improve candidate matching. However, critics argue that AI might be reinforcing biases instead of removing them. After all, an algorithm learns from past data, and if that data contains biased hiring patterns, the AI may unknowingly replicate them.
The Debate: Pros & Cons of AI in Hiring

✅ Why AI is a Game-Changer:
✔ Faster Hiring: AI screens thousands of resumes in seconds, reducing the workload for recruiters.
✔ Objective Decision-Making: AI-based systems focus on skills and qualifications, potentially reducing bias.
✔ Better Candidate Matching: AI can analyse vast amounts of data to find the best fit for a role.

⚠ Concerns About AI in Recruitment:
❌ Bias in Algorithms: AI learns from historical data, which may contain inherent biases, leading to unfair hiring decisions.
❌ Lack of Human Judgment: Can AI assess soft skills, emotional intelligence, and cultural fit as effectively as a human recruiter?
❌ Data Privacy Issues: AI relies on large datasets, raising concerns about data security and ethical hiring practices.
With technology rapidly evolving, we must ask ourselves: Is AI making hiring better or worse?

AI and the Labour Market: Evolution or Revolution?

Many think that – due to AI – we are on the brink of dramatic job losses.

But a new study from the National Bureau of Economic Research (NBER) suggests that, historically, labour market disruptions take decades to unfold.

Looking back over 140 years of employment data, the study finds that:

▪️ The most significant labour market disruptions happened between 1940 and 1970, when agricultural jobs disappeared.

▪️ Since 1990, the pace of occupational change has slowed, despite major advances in digital technology.

▪️ Even during the rise of the internet and automation, the labour market remained surprisingly stable compared to earlier periods.

So, what does this mean for AI?

The study suggests that AI is likely a General-Purpose Technology (GPT) – similar to steam power or electricity.

These innovations transformed work, but their full impact played out over decades.

Likewise, AI is expected to gradually reshape industries, rather than cause mass displacement in the short term.

So, instead of replacing jobs, AI will augment human work and create demand for new skills.

TLDR: businesses and workers should adapt and integrate AI, not expect an immediate employment crisis.

⚠ Concerns About AI in Recruitment:
❌ Bias in Algorithms: AI learns from historical data, which may contain inherent biases, leading to unfair hiring decisions.
❌ Lack of Human Judgment: Can AI assess soft skills, emotional intelligence, and cultural fit as effectively as a human recruiter?
❌ Data Privacy Issues: AI relies on large datasets, raising concerns about data security and ethical hiring practices.

AI and the Labour Market: Evolution or Revolution?

Many think that – due to AI – we are on the brink of dramatic job losses.

But a new study from the National Bureau of Economic Research (NBER) suggests that, historically, labour market disruptions take decades to unfold.

Looking back over 140 years of employment data, the study finds that:

▪️ The most significant labour market disruptions happened between 1940 and 1970, when agricultural jobs disappeared.

▪️ Since 1990, the pace of occupational change has slowed, despite major advances in digital technology.

▪️ Even during the rise of the internet and automation, the labour market remained surprisingly stable compared to earlier periods.

So, what does this mean for AI?

The study suggests that AI is likely a General-Purpose Technology (GPT) – similar to steam power or electricity.

These innovations transformed work, but their full impact played out over decades.

Likewise, AI is expected to gradually reshape industries, rather than cause mass displacement in the short term.

So, instead of replacing jobs, AI will augment human work and create demand for new skills.

TLDR: businesses and workers should adapt and integrate AI, not expect an immediate employment crisis.

Robot & Human Recruiters Collaborating-Deciding Who Gets Hired:

The collaboration between robot recruiters (AI-driven automation) and human recruiters has the potential for a happy ending—but only if managed strategically. The key is augmentation, not replacement—where AI enhances human capabilities rather than eliminating them.

Here’s how this can play out:

Why It Can Work Well (The Happy Ending)

✅ Speed & Efficiency – AI can quickly scan and filter resumes, schedule interviews, and automate repetitive tasks, allowing human recruiters to focus on relationship-building and strategic hiring.
✅ Bias Reduction – AI can help eliminate unconscious bias in the screening process by focusing purely on qualifications and experience (if properly trained).
✅ Enhanced Data Insights – AI can analyze market trends, salary benchmarks, and candidate behavior to help recruiters make better hiring decisions.
✅ Scalability – AI allows recruiters to manage a larger talent pipeline without sacrificing personalization.

Potential Pitfalls (The Unhappy Ending)

⚠️ Lack of Human Touch – AI can’t replace the emotional intelligence, negotiation skills, and rapport-building that human recruiters bring.
⚠️ Bias in AI Models – If the AI is trained on biased data, it can amplify discrimination rather than reduce it.
⚠️ Candidate Experience Issues – Over-reliance on automation can make candidates feel like just another number in the system.
⚠️ Resistance from Recruiters – If recruiters feel threatened rather than empowered by AI, adoption could be slow and ineffective.

What’s the Best Outcome?

The best-case scenario is a hybrid recruiting model, where AI takes care of the grunt work (screening, scheduling, initial outreach), and human recruiters handle relationship-building, negotiation, and strategic hiring decisions.

AI thrives on more rule-based logical tasks, boosting efficiency while reducing human error. When creativity, emotional intelligence or strategic thinking is needed, humans outperform AI.

2️⃣ Cost & Scalability

With no large salaries, tax contributions or onboarding costs, there's usually opportunity to scale output more cost effectively using AI, but it comes down to the task. Complex tasks need complex systems which, while scalable, require upfront costs and maintenance.

3️⃣ Technology Integration

4️⃣ Human Resource Development

The side many people don't focus on - training employees alongside AI increases job satisfaction. Employees develop new skills and have more time to prioritise their focus.

5️⃣ Ethical and Cultural Considerations

Morale amongst your team is key. Clear communication about AI's role is important to empower staff rather than create uncertainty. Transparency is also required for customer-facing AI integrations.


The best approach?

Focus on hiring for strategic and leadership roles but for others, empower existing teams with AI capabilities rather than just adding to the headcount.

This way you'll maximise output, manage costs and maintain staff morale.

A question now on the cards for all businesses looking to scale is - automate with AI or hire human talent?

Here are 5 key points to consider:

1️⃣ Understanding the Task

AI thrives on more rule-based logical tasks, boosting efficiency while reducing human error. When creativity, emotional intelligence or strategic thinking is needed, humans outperform AI.

2️⃣ Cost & Scalability

With no large salaries, tax contributions or onboarding costs, there's usually opportunity to scale output more cost effectively using AI, but it comes down to the task. Complex tasks need complex systems which, while scalable, require upfront costs and maintenance.

3️⃣ Technology Integration

Implementing AI requires infrastructure, investment, and training. While integration is getting smoother, there's still a transition period where training and testing is required, so hiring may be simpler and quicker in these instances.

4️⃣ Human Resource Development

The side many people don't focus on - training employees alongside AI increases job satisfaction. Employees develop new skills and have more time to prioritise their focus.

5️⃣ Ethical and Cultural Considerations

Morale amongst your team is key. Clear communication about AI's role is important to empower staff rather than create uncertainty. Transparency is also required for customer-facing AI integrations.


The best approach?

Focus on hiring for strategic and leadership roles but for others, empower existing teams with AI capabilities rather than just adding to the headcount.

This way you'll maximise output, manage costs and maintain staff morale.

However, critics argue that AI might be reinforcing biases instead of removing them. ✅ Why AI is a Game-Changer:
✔ Faster Hiring: AI screens thousands of resumes in seconds, reducing the workload for recruiters.
✔ Objective Decision-Making: AI-based systems focus on skills and qualifications, potentially reducing bias.
✔ Better Candidate Matching: AI can analyse vast amounts of data to find the best fit for a role.

⚠ Concerns About AI in Recruitment:
❌ Bias in Algorithms: AI learns from historical data, which may contain inherent biases, leading to unfair hiring decisions.
❌ Lack of Human Judgment: Can AI assess soft skills, emotional intelligence, and cultural fit as effectively as a human recruiter?
❌ Data Privacy Issues: AI relies on large datasets, raising concerns about data security and ethical hiring practices.

🚨 The AI Agency Trap: When Marketing Meets Reality 🚨

It’s becoming a trend — companies hiring “AI agencies” with flashy websites and big promises, only to discover too late that these agencies have no real AI or data science expertise.

What happens next?
The company realizes their shiny new AI agent can’t actually do much. Why?
Because AI models need data — clean, structured, meaningful data — and real data science knowledge to train, optimize, and continuously improve those models.

Without that foundation, you’re not getting AI — you’re getting automation theater.

If you’re investing in AI, ask the hard questions:
• Who is building the models?
• What’s their experience with data science and ML engineering?
• How will they handle your data — from preprocessing to model monitoring?

Real AI is 80% data work and 20% modeling magic. Skip the first part, and you don’t have AI — you have a marketing gimmick.

Recruiters deal with stacks of CVs, endless admin, and the pressure to hire fast. AI in ATS systems promises to fix that—but does it actually help, or is it just another buzzword?

Where AI Can Actually Make a Difference

✅ Faster CV Screening – AI can scan and rank candidates based on skills, experience, and relevance in seconds. No more manual filtering through hundreds of applications.

✅ Smarter Matching – Instead of just looking for keywords, AI can identify similar roles, transferable skills, and career patterns to surface strong candidates recruiters might overlook.

✅ Reducing Bias (If Built Properly) – AI doesn’t have gut feelings or unconscious preferences, but it’s only as fair as the data it’s trained on. If designed right, it could help level the playing field.

✅ Better Outreach – AI could predict when someone might be open to a job move based on industry trends and career history, making outreach more targeted instead of just cold emailing.

Where AI Falls Short

❌ It Won’t Replace Recruiters – AI can prioritise CVs, but hiring isn’t just a data problem. Relationships, gut instinct, and human judgement still matter.

❌ It’s Only as Good as Its Training – If an AI is trained on bad hiring data, it will make bad hiring decisions. It needs human oversight to avoid reinforcing biases or filtering out good candidates.

So, will recruiters trust AI?

Right now, most don’t—because AI in hiring is still a black box. If an ATS rejects a great candidate, recruiters need to know why. If AI is going to be useful, it has to be transparent, accurate, and actually save time, not add another layer of admin.

The impact of AI on the workforce is a complex and multifaceted issue, with arguments on both sides regarding whether it will be a savior or a destroyer of jobs.

1️⃣ Potential Job Displacement

AI has the potential to automate many routine and repetitive tasks, which could lead to significant job displacement.

The adoption of AI could exacerbate existing inequalities in the workforce. Women, Black, and Latino workers are underrepresented in STEM fields, and the increased demand for STEM skills due to AI could widen gender, racial, and ethnic wage gaps if not addressed proactively.

2️⃣ Job Creation and Transformation

While AI may automate some jobs, it also has the potential to create new ones. The integration of AI into the workforce could lead to the emergence of new roles that require human oversight, creativity, and emotional intelligence.

AI could complement human workers by taking over routine tasks, allowing employees to focus on more creative and strategic aspects of their jobs. This could lead to a more innovative and adaptable workforce.

3️⃣ Education and Workforce Development

To mitigate the negative impacts of AI on the workforce, it is essential to invest in education and workforce development. Continuous training and upskilling in new technologies like AI are crucial for the current workforce to adapt to the changing job market.

Policies that encourage responsible AI use and promote continual learning are necessary to ensure that the benefits of AI are widely distributed and that marginalized workers are not left behind.

4️⃣ Ethical Considerations

The development and implementation of AI must be guided by ethical considerations to ensure that it benefits humanity. This includes addressing potential privacy concerns and ensuring that AI is used responsibly.

A balanced approach, involving strategic planning and proactive policy-making, is crucial to harnessing the benefits of AI while preparing the workforce for the new landscape of employment.

**Demand vs. Supply Gap** – The explosive demand for 'real' AI experts far exceeds the supply, making competition fierce. Attracting and retaining AI talent requires a different approach—one that prioritizes company culture, innovation, and long-term growth over traditional hiring incentives.

**Hiring Managers Are Wasting Valuable Time** – With more AI-optimized applications, hiring teams spend hours screening resumes, only to discover that many candidates lack real-world experience with AI technologies.

AI is a valuable tool that complements human capabilities rather than replacing them. While AI excels at automating tasks and processing data, it lacks essential human qualities like creativity, emotional intelligence, and ethical reasoning. Here's why AI cannot replace humans:

- **Human Intuition and Creativity**: AI can analyze data patterns but falls short in innovative thinking and generating original ideas, which are uniquely human traits.
- **Dependence on Human Input**: AI learns from human-provided data and lacks independent reasoning or self-awareness beyond its programming.
- **Limited Contextual Understanding**: AI struggles with common sense, ethical dilemmas, and real-world nuances that shape human decision-making.
- **Collaboration Over Replacement**: AI is meant to assist and enhance human capabilities, not replace them, as seen in fields like healthcare where it aids but does not replace the expertise of professionals.
- **Job Evolution, Not Elimination**: AI automates tasks while creating new opportunities, emphasizing the need for humans to focus on roles requiring human skills like empathy and strategic thinking.

In conclusion, AI and humans are better together. AI should be used responsibly to enhance human potential through collaboration, ensuring technology serves society rather than supplanting it.

How is AI Actually Being Used in the Economy? 

New research sheds light on the real-world impact of AI on jobs and industries.

A team of researchers from Anthropic led byandanalyzed 4 million conversations from Claude to understand which economic tasks AI is already performing. Their study, “Which Economic Tasks are Performed with AI? Evidence from Millions of Claude Conversations,” maps AI usage patterns across different occupations using data from the U.S. Department of Labor’s O*NET Database.

Here are five key takeaways that reveal how AI is reshaping work today:

1️⃣ AI’s Growing Economic Role - AI is widely used across industries, but software development and writing tasks dominate, accounting for nearly half of all usage. These fields are seeing the fastest integration of AI-driven workflows.

2️⃣ Deep AI Integration in Select Fields - AI is not evenly distributed across occupations. 4% of jobs use AI for 75%+ of their tasks, while 36% use AI for at least 25%. Adoption is highest in roles requiring critical thinking and writing, such as data science, software engineering, and technical writing—but remains minimal in jobs involving physical labor.

3️⃣ Who’s Using AI? - AI adoption is concentrated in mid-to-high wage jobs, particularly in software-related roles. Interestingly, low-wage jobs (e.g., restaurant workers) and high-wage jobs (e.g., physicians) show relatively low AI adoption, likely due to a mix of regulatory barriers and the nature of these tasks.

4️⃣ AI as a Tool vs. a Replacement - AI is being used in two primary ways: 57% of interactions show augmentation - AI helps humans iterate and improve their work (e.g., writing, coding, brainstorming), while 43% of interactions are automation-driven - AI completes tasks with minimal human input (e.g., generating reports, summarizing documents). AI is both a collaborator and an efficiency booster, depending on the task.

5️⃣ A New Framework for Measuring AI’s Impact – The study introduces an empirical, data-driven method for tracking AI’s evolving role in the economy. As AI capabilities advance, this approach could provide early indicators of where automation and augmentation are heading, helping business leaders, policymakers, and researchers stay ahead of the curve.

AI is a valuable tool that complements human capabilities rather than replacing them. While AI excels at automating tasks and processing data, it lacks essential human qualities like creativity, emotional intelligence, and ethical reasoning. Here's why AI cannot replace humans:

- **Human Intuition and Creativity**: AI can analyze data patterns but falls short in innovative thinking and generating original ideas, which are uniquely human traits.
- **Dependence on Human Input**: AI learns from human-provided data and lacks independent reasoning or self-awareness beyond its programming.
- **Limited Contextual Understanding**: AI struggles with common sense, ethical dilemmas, and real-world nuances that shape human decision-making.
- **Collaboration Over Replacement**: AI is meant to assist and enhance human capabilities, not replace them, as seen in fields like healthcare where it aids but does not replace the expertise of professionals.
- **Job Evolution, Not Elimination**: AI automates tasks while creating new opportunities, emphasizing the need for humans to focus on roles requiring human skills like empathy and strategic thinking.

In conclusion, AI and humans are better together. AI should be used responsibly to enhance human potential through collaboration, ensuring technology serves society rather than supplanting it.

AI AND YOUR CAREER
Assuming you’re interested in your career and want to know what the latest trends are, some recent research may be helpful in your planning. Here are some major points:

·       Currently, most changes in the broad category of artificial intelligence impacting your work, is focused on certain tasks within the job, and not the job itself.
·       In 2022, less than 1% were asking for AI skills in job openings
·       In 2023, only about 2% of job postings asked for AI skills
·       By the end of 2024, more than 25% were asking for some skills or experiences in AI
·       The projections are that by the end of 2025, up to 40% or 50% will be asking for some level of AI skills or experiences.
·       The demand for AI skills is spreading to a broader set of occupations, industries, and local labor markets.
·       The leading sectors using artificial intelligence seems to be in finance, healthcare, retail and manufacturing (which includes engineering, logistics and warehousing).
·       Companies want to leverage new technologies to impact productivity and innovation.
·       While most headlines are directed at professionals who can create, design and implement artificial intelligence, most employers today are looking for those who have the skills and experiences to use the technology, not build them.
·       Hiring managers seek employees who are familiar with some of the basic AI tools and concepts, can effectively work alongside AI systems, and utilize this knowledge to enhance operational efficiency.
·       There’s a recognized skill gap between what organizations are going to need, versus the current skills of their employees.  Organizations are investing in training programs for current employees while recruiting new hires to fill in the gaps.

There’s a clear trend that future employees must have a growing degree of knowledge about artificial intelligence, some skill in using it, and an interest in learning more.  If you don’t have a curiosity about artificial intelligence, how it works, along with an ability to effectively use it, then you’re well behind the curve.  In this competitive world, with a transformational event about to occur which will affect your future, it’s best to be in front of the transition, not behind.

Conclusions:
·       With the trends and demands for AI skills, the expectations for employees to have knowledge and experience in this area will only grow.
·       If you’re not getting proper new-skills training in technology, get it yourself with either self-taught programs on-line or local courses, then seek another job.  If your company doesn’t prepare you for the future, find one who will.  You can’t afford to fall behind.
·       Internal employees who either keep up with the technology demands or develop the skills in advance, will progress in their careers faster than those who are playing catch-up.

The coding landscape is transforming faster than most realize.

Dario Amodei's March 2025 prediction that AI will dominate coding has sparked significant discussion across professional networks, with perspectives ranging from enthusiasm to concern.

The companies making strides in this new era are enhancing their engineering teams by transforming them into AI-augmented units where specialized talent directs increasingly powerful tools.

The most successful organizations are building hybrid teams that combine:
• AI specialists who understand how to prompt, guide, and quality-check AI-generated code
• Strategic architects who design the systems AI helps build
• Experienced developers who provide the contextual understanding and ethical oversight that models cannot replicate

This represents not the end of coding as we know it, but rather its evolution.

I just finished speaking at a CTL global event on the Now and the Next in Hiring and JobSearch. AI was naturally a hot topic. With a Capterra survey showing 73% of Australian respondents to their survey had used it when applying for jobs it's shifting the playing field for hirers and candidates. So what could this mean in 2025 and beyond - here are two of my predictions and what they will mean to jobseekers.

🤔 GenAI is creating a credibility conundrum across all phases of screening with jobseekers using it to assist with everything from resumes, applications and online interview answers through to formal testing.

Implications: We could see a growing focus on proof at all stages. Screening will look for metrics, success stories, verified credentials / skills, and multiple sources of truth. Skills-based hiring and skills assessments might increase along with in-person tests and interviews, gamified simulations and robust referee checks.

Prediction: Hoops before hired may mainstream. Jobseekers may need to go through more steps to get hired. These may include anything from initial AI phone screening and 1-way interviews to in-person interviews and AI-resistant skills-based assessment tools. Skills currency, proficiency and visibility will all be critical. Having the 'right' skills, that can be found and verified by hirers, may equal more opportunities.

🤔 Autoapply and GenAI tools are making it faster and easier to apply but harder to compete.

Implications: In traditional online channels, application volumes may grow and candidates may need to do more to make the interview cut so application rejections could rise. So may job seeker frustration. This could test the resilience and ingenuity of job seekers. Hirers may get frustrated with generic application volumes and increasingly look to proactive approaches including sourcing tools and referrals to find talent.

Prediction: Candidates with strong searchable personal brands and those who know how to use their networks will surge ahead. Powerful brands, warm referrals and introductions will be gold during the job search. AI job search tools will become even more normalised but people may start to recognise their limitations and see them as a tool, rather than a magic wand. The digital-divide may grow. On the upside AI use by hirers may mean jobseekers finally get the transparency they have been seeking with feedback on interviews, application progress and performance insights.

AI is certainly shifting the job search landscape. Even with all my monitoring of this year's hiring trends, predictions are just guesses on what's ahead. The only certainty is AI isn't going anywhere and those who will succeed will be the ones who evolve.

Most enterprises fixated on AI ROI will scale back prematurely.

This is a prediction from Forrester in their 2025 B2C Marketing and CX paper.

Impatience from executives is cited as the driver from pulling back on AI initiatives with:
➡️ 49% expecting a return in 1 - 3 years
➡️ 44% expecting a return in 3 - 5 years

With all the hype that we see connected to AI it is no wonder we all have such high expectations of the technology.

The challenge is, if you pull back you could well be left behind in your industry.

What can we do about this?

In the contact centre/ CX domain, I'll offer a few examples:

▶️ Call Summarisation
This is all the rage and there is an expectation that it works straight away. It doesn't. You have to build out a dictionary of knowledge specific to your product/ service and the language that you use with your customers and/or internal stakeholders. This takes time and iteration. It certainly can be done and definitely has benefits.

▶️ Automated QA
Very similar to call summarisation, the technology is working off a transcript. To get the technology to work for you, you do have to build out markers for what good looks like based on attributes that you are looking to validate in the performance of a call. For one of our accounts we have 3000 markers built out specific to that customer. It is great and it saves heaps of time! There is config involved though.

▶️ Bots
Be it a voice bot or a chat bot, the concept is similar. At the core, you are building out automated workflows to handle customer enquiries at scale. Integration is critical to get the job done and increase your fixed-on-first rates. However, understanding customer demand/ intents, adjusting for them as your customers needs change, and turning the language are all critical. Again this takes time, but well worth the journey if you have the volume to support such an initiative.

💭 As our world transforms with AI, the results won't happen overnight, but it is those that believe and persist that will achieve the productivity benefits that they are chasing and be ahead of the pack!

For most of human history, people worked the land. Then came the Industrial Revolution, shifting workers to factories. In recent decades, industry declined, and the service sector exploded—today, 79% of jobs are in services.

But what happens when algorithms take over services?

Machines first replaced physical labor. Now, AI is automating cognitive tasks once thought uniquely human. Yet, while intelligence has advanced dramatically, consciousness has not—there’s been a decoupling of the two that we once assumed were inseparable.

Agriculture → Industry → Services → … what comes next?

The answer isn’t just about competing with AI—it’s about evolving with it. Throughout history, humans have adapted by redefining work, creativity, and purpose. And while AI may match or surpass human intelligence in many domains, consciousness—our ability to feel, reflect, and create meaning—remains uniquely ours.

Emotions, with all their complexity and messiness, aren’t a flaw of human nature—they’re what make us interesting, unpredictable, and deeply connected to one another. AI can analyze, predict, and optimize, but it doesn’t experience joy, curiosity, or compassion.

The next shift isn’t the end of human value—it’s the beginning of something new.

Normal, everyday workers displaced by AI, directly or indirectly, are left duking it out for fewer, lower-paying jobs. And, the gains of their displacement going to the top, not to the increasingly insecure workers fortunate to survive the cuts.

Enterprise AI automation is rapidly transforming the future of work, impacting industries and job roles across the globe. This research investigates the multifaceted implications of this transformation, exploring its effects on productivity, employment dynamics, required skills, and ethical considerations. Utilizing a mixed-methods approach involving a systematic literature review of ISI-indexed journals and a case study analysis of a Fortune 500 company implementing AI automation, we examine the evolving relationship between humans and intelligent machines in the workplace. Our findings reveal a significant increase in productivity and efficiency due to AI automation, but also a shift in required skills, highlighting the growing demand for roles focused on AI development, management, and oversight. The research also underscores the importance of addressing ethical concerns such as algorithmic bias, job displacement, and the need for responsible AI implementation. We conclude that while AI automation presents immense opportunities for economic growth and innovation, careful consideration of its societal impact and proactive strategies for workforce adaptation are crucial for navigating the changing landscape of work.


Keywords: Artificial Intelligence, Automation, Future of Work, Productivity, Employment, Ethics


Introduction
The rapid advancement and adoption of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and automation technologies are fundamentally reshaping the nature of work. This transformation, often referred to as the Fourth Industrial Revolution, presents both opportunities and challenges for businesses, workers, and society as a whole. From automating routine tasks to augmenting human capabilities, AI is driving significant changes in the workplace, creating new job roles while simultaneously rendering others obsolete.
Existing research has examined various aspects of AI's impact on work, including productivity gains, the changing nature of jobs, and the emergence of new skill requirements. However, there is a need for comprehensive research that integrates these diverse perspectives and explores the complex interplay between technological advancements, organizational strategies, and societal implications.
This research aims to address this gap by investigating the multifaceted implications of enterprise AI automation on the future of work. We explore the impact of AI on productivity, employment dynamics, required skills, and ethical considerations. Through a mixed-methods approach, we aim to provide a nuanced understanding of the transformative potential of AI and offer insights into how organizations and individuals can navigate this evolving landscape.

AI & the Future of Work: What Does the Data Say?

The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) has released a new report analyzing the impact of AI on employment projections (2023–2033). Contrary to popular fears of mass job losses, the findings highlight a more nuanced reality:

- AI is transforming jobs, not just replacing them. Many professions will see increased efficiency and demand, rather than outright displacement.
- Tech roles are growing: Software developers (+17.9%) and data specialists benefit from automation rather than being replaced by it. A surprise for many!
- Routine jobs are declining: AI is taking over repetitive administrative tasks, leading to a reduction in support roles.
- Expertise still matters: Financial advisors, engineers, and regulated professions remain in demand – where human judgment is critical, AI enhances rather than replaces.
- AI adoption is slower than expected: Regulatory barriers, integration complexity, and societal acceptance slow down the impact

Key takeaway from this report: AI is a powerful tool, but not an instant disruptor. The real transformation happens where technology meets human expertise.

🤖 AI's impact on Payroll Professionals 🤖 

Few thoughts after a great coffee meeting this week with a leading Payroll Manager and CFO around an article that stated AI will replace your payroll team within 5 years. 🤔

Whilst we all agreed AI is shaking up payroll, and automation is becoming a bigger part of the process, the idea that payroll professionals will be obsolete is far far far from reality.

Instead my prediction is the role of payroll specialists will evolve; shifting towards consulting, compliance, and technical expertise rather than repetitive processing.

Here are five key ways AI will impact payroll:
Automation of repetitive tasks – Payroll software is already automating calculations, tax deductions, and data entry, reducing human error and increasing efficiency.
Real-time Payroll Processing – AI-driven systems are moving towards continuous payroll, eliminating traditional pay cycles and allowing employees to be paid as they earn.
Compliance and risk management – AI can instantly adapt to new tax laws and regulations, flag anomalies, and reduce compliance risks, making payroll more accurate and less susceptible to audits.
Data-driven decision-making – AI can analyse workforce trends, overtime costs, and payroll discrepancies, providing insights for better financial planning and workforce management.
Enhanced employee experience – Chatbots and AI-driven self-service platforms are empowering employees to access payslips, request changes, and resolve payroll queries without human intervention.

While AI will automate much of the routine work, the need for payroll professionals will remain strong—but the role will change. Payroll specialists will need to upskill, focusing on compliance consulting, system implementation, and strategic payroll advisory rather than just processing pay runs.

AI is not here to replace payroll jobs. It’s here to redefine them. The ones that benefit will be those who can adapt.

The future of talent search isn't AI vs. human expertise—it's finding the right balance between technology and empathy, data and judgment.

One of the key values of AI is that it is cheaper than a human, and you can snag a PhD in most industries for $250k–$300k per year (< $25,000 per month).

As I have posted many times, a key differentiator between AI and humans is that AI lacks motivation, and intentionally so. It takes human input to “motivate” the AI to produce an output.

Much of the hiring process is deciding between multiple, qualified candidates, and evaluating how those people are motivated.

When I deploy AI tools for customers, most of the work is in getting the AI to follow the right cues, and respond with the right “mindset.”

This work is worth it, because the AI I deploy is 1/10 (or less) of the cost of a human counterpart, AND, you only “pay” the AI when it is working. A human agent has to be paid even if no chat requests are coming in.

The strongest use case for OpenAI is to continue pursuing general intelligence, while enabling integration with custom datasets.

Anthropic’s Model Context Protocol, which they have open sourced, should be integrated into every LLM natively, allowing native integration with external services. This would be much more valuable endeavor for OpenAI than specialized AI agents.

AI is the way, but it is not so powerful that we simply discard the cost/benefit analysis. I'm not sure any tool is.

Can AI really automate our jobs?

That seems to be the big question for most people when it comes to AI.

Well, new interesting research has tried to answer this. It tested seven LLMs: Claude, GPT-4, Gemini, Amazon Nova, Meta Llama, and Alibaba Qwen.

Their goal was to see how well the models could complete real world tasks and real world companies.

They gave the AIs 175 different tasks you'd find in a typical workplace.

Things like:
— Writing and fixing code
— Managing team projects
— Dealing with HR stuff
— Handling company finances

Here is a summary of the results:

— The best-performing AI was Claude 3.5 Sonnet.
— Despite it being the best, Claude could complete 24% of its tasks.
— Each task relatively expensive, costing about $6.34 in computing power.
— The AI often needed around 30 attempts to figure things out.
— Other models, like GPT-4o took fewer steps, but their success rate was quite low (~14 steps).
— AI agents did best with technical stuff like coding. But struggled with things that required common sense and social skills.
— Sometimes the AIs would make up solutions instead of solving the problem.

So what does this mean?

As of today, AI is nowhere near ready to replace human workers.

Their goal was to see how well the models could complete real world tasks and real world companies.

They gave the AIs 175 different tasks you'd find in a typical workplace.

Things like:
— Writing and fixing code
— Managing team projects
— Dealing with HR stuff
— Handling company finances

Here is a summary of the results:

— The best-performing AI was Claude 3.5 Sonnet.
— Despite it being the best, Claude could complete 24% of its tasks.
— Each task relatively expensive, costing about $6.34 in computing power.
— The AI often needed around 30 attempts to figure things out.
— Other models, like GPT-4o took fewer steps, but their success rate was quite low (~14 steps).
— AI agents did best with technical stuff like coding. But struggled with things that required common sense and social skills.
— Sometimes the AIs would make up solutions instead of solving the problem.

So what does this mean?

As of today, AI is nowhere near ready to replace human workers.

Case in point: I recently automated a complex Excel-based risk assessment tool. The master Excel file is classic: dozens of interconnected worksheets, hundreds of columns, and millions of rows. It definitely won't work when Automatic calculation is enabled, and would crash Excel once every few hours. Preparing the input data often took hours, and only one person can fix it if something goes wrong.

I’ve worked with Excel for over 20 years and thought I’m pretty good at it - until I get to know this file :)

In the past, to get this task done I would have spent weeks manually mapping the logic onto an A2-sized piece of paper, and would probably need help from others if the deadline is tight. But this is 2024, so I pasted all the formulae to an LLM and asked it to map dependencies, remove redundancies, explain the logic in layman terms, then generate the replacement code. The bulk of the work was done in less than two days, leaving ample time for coffee and self reflection.

Could it be done without AI? Absolutely yes - but at a much higher cost in time and effort. And when it's done it's quite likely that there's no time left for documentation. Meaning we'd shift the complexity from Excel to SQL/Python, and the business reliance on one business guru to that same business guru PLUS that dude in the data team. The LLM in this case generates the technical and business explanations quite effortlessly IF the code works.

Did the code work on the first try? Hell no. Sometimes I wondered whether it's quicker just to go back to the A2-sized logic map, but the final result actually spoke for itself.

Other fun facts:

- It feels like working with an 8-year-old genius, which explains why the code doesn't always work. The difference is that it's capabilities are improved at a stunning pace and it doesn't age like Tam :)
- I used a few LLMs just to observe how they performed: chagpt o1, chatgpt 4o, claude 3.5 - either directly or via GitHub copilot. No clear winner came out but I think o1 is slightly better but consistently inconsistent. Haven't tried Gemini 2.0 which was not available when I started the work.
- I guess the use cases where LLMs are adding the most values now are those with a more deterministic outcomes like the one above. Ironically the very same LLMs used elsewhere are generating so much noise that we fail to identify practical use cases that are right under our noses

So yes, the Tam using AI is slowly - but very surely - replacing the old Tam. And I'm feeling good about it.
